we've positioned ourself in the middle of a two-sided market on the left-hand
side of this diagram we have the satellite operators some of them are incumbents which may have their own
infrastructure may have already invested significantly in that some of them are
new entrants who haven't built any infrastructure yet there's benefits to both with the Skywatch platform for the
incumbents there's an opportunity to remove a significant dollar amount from their balance sheet with the investment
they have in storage and processing costs for the new entrants being able to check a box off to be able to deliver
this data to a large market is something their investors look for on the right
side of this diagram is the demand side and we've heard if you're in this room
earlier we've heard from a number of companies that are leveraging this data for analytics and building some pretty

something that they can use for time series and being able to understand that the data is normalized to a degree where
their models can consume that and the data is trustworthy so how did we build
this platform about a year and a half ago I joined Sky Watch and had an interesting problem it was a good
problem and a bad problem at the same time it was there is no code there is no
system how do you build it so we knew we had to take a couple of things into
account the first being a goal of not doing any significant system refactoring
for the next five years how could we choose an architecture that we felt we could bet on for the next five years the
second was how do we think about systems in the past that we've worked with many of the monolithic systems some of that
system may have worked well some may have not have worked well how are we going to iterate and improve on a system
in the next couple of years in a way that that scales with the company so we
developed our engineering principles we post these on the wall at our office and they help us make decisions every day
the first decision we make was to employ a microservices architecture if you're
not familiar with microservices essentially they take what could have been a monolithic application and we
break it down into small little functional pieces a good example I like to share with that is the ability to
send an email now for us to send an email we call our send email micro service its job is to send an email it's
a black box we don't care how it works we just know there's a contractual obligation within that micro service to
receive an email address a subject and a body and to respond back with a success
or a failure now when you're building a micro service you have ultimate flexibility to do it however you want
and in one case a developer may stand up an SMTP server may decide they're gonna
manage IP addresses may get a decide they're gonna deal with being classified as spam another person may choose Sun
grader or MailChimp or other services out there and do that I'm just gonna make a call to them to me as a system or
as an architect I don't care I just know whenever I call that micro service that send mail will be executed we also made
a decision to go 100% serverless and Greg had talked about some of the drawbacks of this choice and he's right
but we made the decision to go 100% server lists because our system we designed to have high throughput not
necessarily low latency our customers can tolerate if something takes 10
minutes whereas in Gregor's case they can't if you're on a website and you're clicking on something you want that
instant response we don't have that paradigm with our use case and finally
we decided to give our engineers freedom and autonomy this means and this is a
Netflix term if you happen to have seen the Netflix culture deck that they've posted and has been famous since 2009
freedom and autonomy is something they give engineers and we give hours to be able to choose the solutions that are
best for their situation now the prior slide I talked about a hundred percent serverless within that within that
guardrail is what we say and a paved road is something where we have done that in the

micro-service blueprint when we started down this path we started to do a lot of

simple serverless micro service there's there's documentation on how to build a
HelloWorld micro service on Amazon and it consists of these three components api gateway which manages that inbound
restful api call lambda which does some processing work to that data and
dynamodb which allows you to store data or retrieve data all in a serverless way so we took this and we started to run
with it and the first thing we found was that we were having a little bit of latency with everything running through
API gateway with every micro service having every micro service as its own unique restful api call was something
that was slowing us down we also found that in some cases we would need a restful api interface if we were going
to build micro services or interact with restful api outside of our organization so we added to our server list template
and we built something called our discovery service and actually I believe Amazon has has a tool for this now at
the time they didn't and ours has a bit more flexibility that I'll tell you about so discovery allows our micro
services to interact with other micro services by simply calling their name it needs not to know of where they are of
if the invocation is restful or if it's a lambda invoke or anything about them going back to my sendmail example we
just need to be able to call discovery and say please call send mail and deliver this discovery maps that to a
URL and deals with all the details of delivery to that particular area on the
right side here of this document we are this slide we've also added a few extra pieces along the way so whether it's
making sure that API is secure or that micro service is secure rather whether we're tracing using the tools like x-ray
weather adding traditional logging that's output to cloud watch or separation of
analytics logging those are all baked into our server list templates we've
also picked up a number of other AWS server list tools at the top of this diagram you can see these are sort of
entry points so whether it's whether we're deploying code through cloud formation whether we're receiving web
requests with cloud front or whether we're injecting data into our analytics environment with Kinesis firehose these
are all managed for us and moving down the stack we're using simple notification service when we need to

tool called Fargate to process the data the bottom line is we check our

mentioned some of the drawbacks to lambda there is you know lambda is marketed and is thought of as a server
list component by those who use it the reality is behind the scenes that are containers that are and servers that are
running it and there is a time that it takes to do what's called a cold start so that is one of the drawbacks the

we're delivering that as a directed NDVI to an end customer we know exactly how
much each step cost along the way we no longer to have a large fixed cost of
infrastructure that's running in the background for peak loads even when that

much better as we're delivering these products to our customer we also have

it's excessively painful we will reconsider for us maintaining relational
data in to no sequel tables doesn't make any sense that qualifies as excessively

secondly extending graph QL if you're not familiar with graph QL this is a
language that allows an API call to rip request complex data from a system and
receive that back in one response so an example would be if you were going to
call an API say a Facebook API and there was a post and a bunch of people liked
it and you wanted to understand the profiles of the people who liked it that would take multiple calls you'd have to
make one call to get the post and get back the IDS of the people who who made that who made those likes you would have
to make another call to then get more details about those and loop through multiple times so potentially dozens or
hundreds of calls with graph QL you're able to make that call once make your request in a sequel like issue format
and receive all of your results back and Amazon has a product for that called appsync that we're using also a server
